curam.util.type
Class Money

java.lang.Object
  curam.util.type.Money
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<Money>
public final class Money
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<Money>

Money represents a currency value to two decimal places. Money is constructed with a double-precision floating point value which is rounded or truncated to the nearest cent/penny depending on a flag passed to the constructor. Money is intended to be used to round and store floating point values in a way that they can be reliably tested for equality. It is NOT intended to be used in computations... for this you should use the appropriate floating point datum. Use Money in a series of calculations at the point where it is appropriate (in your design) to perform rounding.

The range and accuracy of the Money data type are the same as for the Java double data type, where the double stores the number of cents/pence.

See Also:
Serialized Form

Constructor Detail

Money

public Money(double amount)
      throws java.lang.RuntimeException
Construct Money from a floating point currency amount. The amount is rounded to the nearest cent/penny, up on 0.5 or greater, down otherwise.

Parameters:
amount - The money value to be stored. This value should not be larger than (Double.MAX/100).
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - A Money was constructed with a double that is Not A Number or Infinite.

Money

public Money(double amount,
             boolean round)
      throws java.lang.RuntimeException
Construct Money from a floating point currency amount. If round is set to true, the amount is rounded to the nearest cent/penny, up on 0.5 or greater, down otherwise. If round is false, the value is truncated to the next lowest number of cents/pence. You can use the supplied constants for rounding/truncation, e.g. 

 Money m = new Money(1.246, Money.kTruncate);

Parameters:
amount - The money value to be stored. This value should not be larger than (Double.MAX/100).
round - Specifies whether rounding (true) or truncation (false) should occur.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - A Money was constructed with a double that is Not A Number or Infinite.

Construct Money from an amount passed in.

Parameters:
amount - The Money value to be stored.

public Money(java.lang.String amount)
      throws java.lang.RuntimeException
Construct Money from an amount passed in, handling the necessary localization issues (for example the use of a comma in French and German strings to indicate what is a normally a decimal point in English).

Parameters:
amount - The Money value to be stored.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - A Money was constructed with a double that is Not A Number or Infinite.

doConversion

public static double doConversion(java.lang.String strValue)
                           throws java.lang.NumberFormatException
Converts a string to a double, handling the necessary localization issues (for example the use of a comma in French and German strings to indicate what is a normally a decimal point in English).

Parameters:
strValue - The string to be converted.
Returns:
The double value constructed from the string. An empty string is converted to zero.
Throws:
java.lang.NumberFormatException - The string is not a valid number.
